metadata.title: Carbon foam-supported CoN nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes hybrids as bifunctional reduction electrocatalyst

Fig. 6 Carbon foam-supported CoN nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes hybrids as bifunctional reduction electrocatalyst Huan-Fang Xu Investigation Writing – original draft a Quan-Guo Zhai Data curation Validation a Yu-Cheng Jiang Data curation Validation a Hao Huang Formal analysis Validation Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Shu-Ni Li Methodology Project administration Resources Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Science of Shaanxi Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710062, PR China Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Science of Shaanxi Province School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shaanxi Normal University Xi'an 710062 PR China Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Science of Shaanxi Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'’an 710062, PR China. b School of Sustainable Energy Materials and Science, Jinhua Advanced Research Institute, Jinhua 321000, PR China School of Sustainable Energy Materials and Science Jinhua Advanced Research Institute Jinhua 321000 PR China School of Sustainable Energy Materials and Science, Jinhua Advanced Research Institute, Jinhua 321000, PR China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. CoN nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes hybrid supported on carbon foam (INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF) electrocatalyst was synthesized by one-step pyrolysis of irregular nanoparticles ZIF-67 (ZIF-67-INPs) with melamine foam. The INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF electrocatalyst exhibited remarkable activity for ORR with a high half-wave potential of 0.862 V vs. RHE, and a good HER electrocatalytic activity with overpotential of 180 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 102.5 mV dec−1. This electrocatalyst can be a promising bifunctional alternative for both ORR and HER. This work provides a new insight for the design of new-type multi-functional electrocatalysts for practical applications. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords ZIF-67 CoN/CNTs hybrids Carbon foam Oxygen reduction reaction Electrocatalyst 1 Introduction The overdependence on traditional fossil fuel has resulted in rising energy shortage and environmental pollution problems. Nowadays, developing new-type energy conversion and storage technologies, such as a water splitting device [1–3], metal-air battery [4,5], Li-ion battery [6] and fuel cell [7] become urgent to break through the energy predicament. In particular, hydrogen production, metal-air battery and fuel cell are dependent on electrochemical reduction reactions, including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, owing to their sluggish kinetics, the introduction of electrocatalyst into these reduction reactions is essential to accelerate the reaction rate and meet the demands of these energy devices. Up to now, Pt-based nanomaterials are considered as the optimal electrocatalysts, but the limited resource of Pt gives rise to a high-cost and restricts the large-scope application. Also, toxicity effects of carbon monoxide and alcohols also limits the utilization of Pt toward ORR and HER. Although many strategies have been employed to reduce the cost and increase the stability of Pt-based materials, including single-atom Pt [8] and Pt-based alloys [9,10], most of these electrocatalysts are still hard to fundamentally break the electrocatalytic bottleneck of electrochemical reduction reactions. Non-noble metal carbonitride (M/NC) has attracted increasing interest as a proper electrocatalyst candidate toward electrochemical reduction reactions, owing to its high activity and stability, low cost, and easy synthesis [11–13]. Particularly, the M/NC derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), constructed by coordinating metal ions and organic ligands [14–17], can exhibit enhanced electrocatalytic activity. In the process of MOFs pyrolysis, the metal linkages are reduced and form M/NC nanoparticles, which are uniformly distributed on carbon substrate [18,19]. This strategy can make the M/NC inherit some typical characteristics of MOFs structure, including large surface area, porous structure, and heteroatom doping [20,21]. Also, pyrolysis process can bring excellent stability, high conductivity and active metal sites to M/NC [22,23]. Among the numerous MOFs structures, ZIFs are reasonable precursors to synthesize M/NC nanomaterials due to the high crystallinity, abundant subgroup structure and excellent stability. ZIF-67, a typical ZIF structure, consists of cobalt ions (Co2+) and 2-methylimidazole, which is recently utilized as precursor to prepare various Co-based nanomaterials, such as oxides, nitrides and sulphides [24–26]. Beyond other MOFs structures, ZIF-67 not only has higher tunability of porous structure [27], but exhibits better environmental friendliness, which can be prepared in water [28,29]. Besides, the introduction of surface-active agent (PVP, P120) is advantageous to cut-down the size of ZIF-67 nanostructure (ca. ≤200 nm) [13,30]. The ultra-small ZIF-67 nanostructure is instrumental in forming ultra-small Co-based nanoparticles with high active surface and abundant exposed CoN sites. According to these advantages, ZIF-67 nanostructure can be regarded as reasonable precursor to achieve efficient INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF bifunctional electrocatalyst toward ORR and HER processes. Herein, by using the irregular nanoparticles ZIF-67 (ZIF-67-INPs) as precursor, INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF nanocatalyst was synthesized via a facile pyrolysis treatment. The INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF nanocatalyst consists of small particles (~ 5 nm), which can expose numerous active metal sites and act as bifunctional electrocatalyst for both ORR and HER processes. Moreover, in this work, carbon foam (CF) was also introduced into the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF as conductive substrate to restrain aggregation of nanoparticles that would lead to a severely reduced electroactive catalytic area of nano-materials and in turn to a low electrocatalytic activity. The three-dimensional network of CF can provide large surface area, high porosity, and good hydrophilicity for the INPs-CoN/CNTs nanocatalyst [31,32]. Besides, the excellent conductivity of CF can endow the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF nanocatalyst with an accelerated electron-transfer [33]. Based on these characteristics, INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF exhibits a remarkable ORR electroactivity with a half-wave potential of 0.862 V (vs. RHE) and a proper electron transfer number (ca. 3.8). Additionally, for electrochemical HER, this material exhibits also a good activity with a low overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (180 mV) and Tafel slope (102.5 mV dec−1). Thus, INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF can be a reasonable bifunctional electrocatalyst for both ORR and HER. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and chemicals Co(NO3)2·6H2O, H2O2, 2-methylimidazole, sulphuric acid and isopropyl alcohol were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. Nafion solution (5% at ethanol) and commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst (20 wt% Pt/C) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and Johnson- Matthey separately. Shanghai Kelai provided melamine foam for this work. 2.2 Pre-treatment of melamine sponge (MS) Melamine sponge (2 × 2 × 3.5 cm) was washed by deionization water and ethanol to remove impurities on the surface. Before utilizing, the H2O2 solution (30%) was employed to treat the surface of melamine foam for increasing the hydrophilicity, then the pre-treated melamine foam was rinsed by deionization water and dried at 60 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of ZIF-67-PHs and ZIF-67-INPs The solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.755 g) in 50 mL methanol and the solution of 2-methylimidazole(1.67 g) in 50 mL methanol was mixed and sonicated for 10 min. The mixture was stirred for another 24 h and filtered. The precipitate was washed with methanol and dried at 60 °C. The as-synthesized MOFs with polyhedrons morphology was named ZIF-67-PHs. In the synthesis of ZIF-67-INPs, aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2 and aqueous solution 2-methylimidazole were mixed and sonicated for only 10 min, where the product was obtained as irregular nanoparticles (ZIF-67-INPs). 2.4 Synthesis of PHs-CoN/CNTs, PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF and INPs -CoN/CNTs-CF ZIF-67-PHs was placed in a tubular furnace and heated to 800 °C for 2 h under N2 gas atmosphere. The solid mixture obtained after cooling to room T was washed with 0.5 M H2SO4 at 80 °C for 24 h and then dried at 60 °C. The product was named as PHs-CoN/CNTs. The pre-treated melamine foam was immersed into a suspension of ZIF-67-PHs or ZIF-67-INPs in 20 mL ethanol. Then, the procedure was the same as that of PHs-CoN/CNTs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD patterns and SEM images of ZIF-67 precursors In this work, the ZIF-67 precursors were prepared in methanol for 24 h and in water for 10 min. The XRD patterns of the ZIF-67 precursors (Fig. S1) matches well with the simulated pattern, suggesting the successful formation of ZIF-67 both in methanol and water. The SEM images showed that ZIF-67-PHs have uniformed rhombic polyhedrons (Fig. S2). However, ZIF-67 precursors formed in water displayed irregular nanoparticles (Fig. S3). Melamine sponge is usually utilized as the precursor of conductive carbon substrate, owing to the abundant 3D porous networks and the bargain prices. The SEM images showed the melamine sponge had macroporous structure and is a reasonable platform for the growth of ZIF-67-PHs nanocrystal (Fig. S4a). However, the surface of melamine sponge was too smooth to achieve the nucleation of ZIF-67 (Fig. S4b). The post-processing with H2O2 can make the surface of ZIF-67-PHs rough to expose more organic groups, including carboxyl and hydroxyl, which are conducive to the adhesion of ZIF-67-PHs nanocrystal nucleus (Fig. S4 c and d) [13], even though ZIF-67-PHs are hard to be grown uniformly due to the oversized nanoparticles (Fig. S5). However, ZIF-67-INPs membrane can firmly be attached and uniformly cover the surface of melamine sponge (Fig. S6). 3.2 Characterization of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF The melamine sponge (MS) was transformed as a 3D carbon foam (CF) with rough surface through pyrolysis process at 800 °C (Fig. S7a and b). This phenomenon might be caused by the releasing of carbon nitride type gaseous species (such as C2N2 +, C3N2 + and/or C3N3 +) and forming the CN bond during the pyrolysis process [34]. After pyrolysis, PHs-ZIF-67 nanocrystal was transformed to PHs-CoN/CNTs (Fig. S8). Besides, the Co ions present in ZIF-67 acted as catalyst to reform amorphous carbon, originated from the organic ligand of ZIF-67, to form CNTs structure during this pyrolysis. Moreover, the polyhedral appearance of the precursors can still be clearly observed. When PHs-ZIF-67 was adsorbed on MS, PHs-CoN/CNTs grow on the surface of CF (Fig. S7c and d). Calcination of the ZIF-67-INPs on melamine sponge resulted in the complete disappearance of morphology of the precursor. The XRD, SEM and TEM techniques were carried out to investigate the composition and micro-morphology of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF material. The SEM images (Fig. 1a-d) show that numerous interweaved carbon tube anchored on the surface of CF. Besides, the TEM images indicate the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF sample contains numerous CoN nanoparticles, which are sealed in the interweaved carbon tubes (Fig. 1e). The prepared CNTs structure can increase the conductivity of catalysts to improve the properties for electrochemical ORR and HER. Also, the CNTs structure wrapped the CoN nanoparticles, which can effectively protect active CoN sites from agglomeration and acid condition in the electrocatalytic process to improve the stability of these catalysts. The enlarged HRTEM image shows that the lattice spacing of the nanoparticles is 0.20 nm, which corresponds to the (111) crystal plane of cobalt nitride (Fig. 1f). Thus, the CoN nanoparticles are hard to be removed by washing with 0.5 M H2SO4 due to the protection offered by carbon tubes of an average size of about 15 nm (Fig. 1e). The XRD patterns (Fig. 1g) show that PHs-CoN/CNTs, PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF and INPs -CoN/CNTs-CF all can be classified into the crystal structure of CoN. The diffraction peaks at 44, 51 and 71° 2theta can be attributed to the (111), (200) and (220) of crystal facets of CoN structure (JCPDS No. 41–0943). In the powder XRD pattern of pure CF, an obvious wide peak appears at 26° (Fig. 1g), assigned to the (002) crystal facet of graphitic carbon, suggesting that high temperature can endow carbon foam with a high crystallinity. The chemical composition of INPs -CoN/CNTs-CF sample was investigated by EDX and mapping method. EDX spectrum indicates the existence of C, N, Co elements (Fig. 1 h and i). The surface composition and electronic states of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF were also disclosed by XPS. The signals of C, N, and Co elements clearly appeared in the full XPS spectra of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF sample, which is in good agreement with the EDX mapping result (Fig. 2a). As for the C 1 s XPS spectrum, the three peaks centered at 284.7, 285.9 and 288.9 eV belong to the CC, CN and CO bonding, respectively (Fig. 2b). In Co 2p XPS spectrum, the main peaks at 780.8 and 797.0 eV can be separately attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbitals of Co. Besides, the XPS peak of Co 2p3/2 orbital can be deconvoluted into three peaks, which are ascribed to Co0 (778.3 eV), CoO (780.5 eV) and CoN (782.7 eV), suggesting that the high-active CoN structure toward ORR exists in the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF sample (Fig. 2c) [13,16]. There are three peaks at 398.3, 399.1 and 400.9 eV in N 1 s XPS spectrum which can be assigned to pyridine-N, pyrrolic-N and graphite-N, respectively (Fig. 2d). Usually, the pyridine-N is considered as the active structure with strong capability of electron donating to enhance the electrocatalytic activity for ORR and HER, and the graphite-N structure can increase the conductivity to enhance the rate of the ORR and HER process [35]. To study the structural characteristics of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF, the surface area and porous structure were measured by N2 gas adsorption/desorption isotherms. The ZIF-67-PHs precursor showed a type-I isotherm and the specific surface area was 1786 m2/g due to its very much microporous structure (Fig. S9a). In contrary, after pyrolysis, the specific surface area of PHs-CoN/CNTs sample was significantly reduced to 242 m2/g (Fig. S9b). The INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF sample showed a type-IV isotherm with mesoporous and microporous structure (Fig. S9c), and the specific surface area was 484 m2/g, which was derived from the 3D porous structure of CF. The pore-size distribution showed that the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF contains abundant micropores and mesopores (Fig. S9c). As the result, the high specific surface area and porous structure largely eliminated mass transfer resistances during the ORR and HER process. Like the INPs -CoN/CNTs-CF sample, the PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF also showed a type-IV isotherm. The specific surface area was close to 237 m2/g, which was mainly originated form the presence of micropores (Fig. S9d). These results indicate that the introduction of carbon foam not only increased the specific surface area, but also provided mesoporous structure, which is instrumental for the interaction between electrolyte and electrocatalyst. Thus, through the mesoporous structure, the dissolved oxygen can effectively diffuse into the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF and react on the surface CoN active sites and greatly enhanced the dynamics to achieve efficient ORR and HER electrocatalytic activity. Moreover, the thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) technique was used in air to study the loading amount of Co in the PHs-CoN/CNTs and INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF samples, which amounted to 25.4 wt% and 20.9 wt%, respectively (Fig. S10 and 11). After TGA testing, the XRD patterns indicated the presence of Co3O4 (Fig. S12). 3.3 ORR activity of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF ORR is an important half-reaction of fuel cells and metal-air batteries. The extent of ORR of electrocatalysts determines the efficiency of these energy devices. The ORR performances of various electrodes were investigated by using a typical three-electrode system in 1 M KOH solution [4]. The electrochemical behavior of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF sample was recorded by cyclic voltammetry (CV) testing. The CV curve of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF exhibits a square-like behavior in N2-saturated electrolyte (Fig. 3a). On the contrary, an obvious peak at 0.837 V (vs. RHE) exists in the CV curve under O2-saturated conditions, which indicates reduction of the dissolved oxygen on the surface of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was also employed to study the electrocatalytic activity of commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst, INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF, pure CF, PHs-CoN/CNTs, and PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF for ORR (Fig. 3b). The INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF sample exhibited an optimal onset potential (0.938 V vs. RHE), better than that of pure CF (0.909 V vs. RHE), PHs-CoN/CNTs (0.881 V vs. RHE) and PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF (0.898 V vs. RHE). Similarly, for half-wave potential (Fig. 3c), the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF (0.862 V vs. RHE) exhibited the largest one compared to pure CF (0.679 V vs. RHE), PHs-CoN/CNTs (0.824 V vs. RHE) and PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF (0.844 V vs. RHE), which is even better than the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst (0.856 V vs. RHE). This result indicated that the introduction of CF can enhance the ORR electrocatalytic activity, owing to the strong interaction and electronic coupling between pure CF and INPs-CoN/CNTs nanoparticles. Compared to current ORR electrocatalysts, the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF still has a distinct advantage as reported in Table S1. To gain insight into the kinetics of the ORR process, the Tafel slopes of these electrocatalysts were calculated. The Tafel slope of ORR conducted on the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF was down to 47.9 mV dec−1, much lower than that of commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst (96.6 mV dec−1), pure CF (152.4 mV dec−1), PHs-CoN/CNTs (137.9 mV dec−1) and PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF (74.6 mV dec−1), suggesting that the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF has the fastest kinetics of ORR (Fig. 3d). The excellent ORR electrocatalytic activity of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF is originated from its structural advantages. Firstly, the numerous highly active CoN sites exposed on the surface of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF should be noted. Secondly, the porous conductive network of CF not only can provide effective channel for fast electron and mass transfer but brings also additional surface exposing numerous CoN sites for electrocatalysis. Thirdly, the N element in CF of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF endowed with a better hydrophilicity, can promote the combination of dissolved oxygen and CoN sites. Finally, the electronegativity of N (3.0) is larger than that of C element (2.5), which makes a higher charge density for C sties and provides an assistance effect for enhanced ORR and HER electrocatalytic processes. The electron-transfer number (n) is a vital factor to estimate the ORR performance of electrocatalysts. In this work, we adopted RDE working mode to calculate the electron-transfer number of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF sample. Due to the continuously shortened diffusion layer, a typical increase of the catalytic current with increasing rotation rate was observed for the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF (Fig. 4a). Based on the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) equation, the calculated n value of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF was close to 3.8, which suggests that the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF exhibits a four-electron selectivity and the product in the ORR process is mainly water (Fig. 4b). Meantime, the RRDE result showed a negligible ring current (Fig. 4c). In addition, as shown in Fig. S13, the Tafel slope (69.5 mV dec−1) of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF obtained after RRDE test was less than that of commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst (102.4 mV dec−1), further showing its fast electrocatalytic kinetics. After calculation, the yield of H2O2 was about 11% at 0.3 V vs. RHE, and the n value was 3.8, similar to the result of RDE (Fig. 4d). At the same time, the ORR polarization curve of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF, before and after the OER test, showed that the catalytic material in the OER process had been oxidized. The half-wave potential was negatively shifted by 64 mV (Fig. S14), which further shows that cobalt nitride has a positive effect on catalyzing the ORR process. The stability of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF was evaluated by various electrochemical techniques such as CV and LSV. The CV curve of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF at 5000-th cycle was found similar to the curve at the 1st cycle (Fig. 5a). In LSV curve, after the 5000-th cycle, the half-wave of INPs-CoN/CTS-CF displayed 5 mV negative shift to the curve at the 1st cycle (Fig. 5b). As control, the half-wave of commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst displayed 11 mV negative shift to the curve at the 1st cycle. These results indicate that the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF has a better stability than the 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst. For practical applications toward fuel cells, methanol resistance is another factor to be considered. After adding 0.1 M methanol, the LSV curve of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF showed no trace of variation to the original curve (Fig. 5c), indicating that the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF has an excellent resistance to methanol. However, with regards to the 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst, the LSV curve after adding methanol had an obvious current peak at 0.78 V (vs. RHE) due to methanol electrooxidation (Fig. 5d). 3.4 HER electrocatalytic activity of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF The electrocatalytic activity of the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) was measured by the LSV technique in 0.5 M H2SO4. As control, PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF, PHs-CoN/CNTs, pure CF and commercial 20 wt% Pt/C electrocatalysts were also studied under the same conditions. The current densities were normalized to the geometric area of the working electrode. LSV curves displayed that INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF had an excellent activity with overpotentials of 180 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6a and b), which is much better than that of PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF (211 mV), PHs-CoN/CNTs (203 mV), and pure CF (470 mV). The HER overpotential of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF in 0.5 M H2SO4 was even comparable to those cobalt hybrids nanocatalysts as reported in Table S2. The performance of the electrocatalysts was affected by the chemical kinetics of the reaction. Tafel slopes of HER for INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF, PHs-CoN/CNTs-CF and PHs-CoN/CNTs electrocatalysts were found to be: 102.5, 132.1 and 120.8 mV dec−1, respectively (Fig. 6c). This result indicates that the fast kinetics brings a good HER electrocatalytic activity for the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF solid. The improved HER activity can be attributed to the very small CoN nanoparticles present and the porous network structure of the solid. The unique structure of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF is not only to provide abundant active centres but also becomes advantageous to electrolyte transfer during the HER process. 4 Conclusions We have developed an effective strategy to achieve efficient non-noble metal carbonitride electrocatalyst for ORR via pyrolysis of INPs-ZIF-67 on CF. In alkaline electrolyte, the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF exhibited an excellent ORR electrocatalytic activity with a high half-wave potential (0.862 V vs. RHE) and four-electron selectivity. The excellent electrocatalytic activity of INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF was originated from: (i) the excellent activity of the CoN sites; (ii) the porous network structure exposing numerous CoN sites and allowing fast mass transfer; (iii) the lone pair electrons of N in INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF endowed with a better hydrophilicity, which can promote the combination of dissolved oxygen and CoN sites on INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF; (iv) the larger electronegativity of N (3.0) than that of C element (2.5), which makes a higher positive charge density for C sites and improves the activity. Moreover, owing to the stable chemical structure and good catalytic selectivity, the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF exhibits a promising electrocatalytic stability for ORR and resistance to methanol. Based on these structural advantages, the INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF also showed a good electrocatalytic activity for HER. This work provides the way for a cost-effective and high-efficiency route for ORR and HER electrocatalysis, which can promote its practical application for new sustainable energy devices. coredata.dc:description: CoN nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes hybrid supported on carbon foam (INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF) electrocatalyst was synthesized by one-step pyrolysis of irregular nanoparticles ZIF-67 (ZIF-67-INPs) with melamine foam. The INPs-CoN/CNTs-CF electrocatalyst exhibited remarkable activity for ORR with a high half-wave potential of 0.862 V vs. RHE, and a good HER electrocatalytic activity with overpotential of 180 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 102.5 mV dec−1. This electrocatalyst can be a promising bifunctional alternative for both ORR and HER. This work provides a new insight for the design of new-type multi-functional electrocatalysts for practical applications.

coredata.dc:title: Carbon foam-supported CoN nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes hybrids as bifunctional reduction electrocatalyst
